channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israeli Strikes Kill Over 20 and Hit Another U.N. Building in Gaza
item.description: The Israeli military said it was targeting militants operating in a U.N. school being used as a shelter in Nuseirat. A second strike caused fatalities in Al-Mawasi, the Gazan Health Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Julian Barnes and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: A U.N. school now used as a shelter in Nuseirat refugee camp in Gaza after an Israeli strike on Tuesday.

item.title: Heat Wave in Ukraine Further Strains Its Electricity Grid
item.description: To prevent a collapse of the electricity system, crippled by months of Russian attacks, the authorities have imposed rolling blackouts. Experts say it’s a harbinger of what’s to come this winter.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Generators powering a row of shops in the Podil neighborhood of Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, on Tuesday.

item.title: King’s Speech Promises a Changed U.K.
item.description: From plans to tackle climate change to ending the role of hereditary legislators, the ceremonial King’s Speech showcased the progressive priorities of Britain’s Labour government.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: King Charles III formally opened Britain’s Parliament on Wednesday, presenting the priorities of Britain’s new Labour government.

item.title: How France Blocked the Far Right
item.description: The French had a far-right government before, one that collaborated with the Nazis. When casting ballots even today, that is not an easy thing to forget.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Posters showing candidates for France’s second round of legislative elections outside the City Hall in Saintes last week.

item.title: Russian Orthodox Church Wages a ‘Holy War’ Against Satanism, and the West
item.description: A battle has erupted in Moldova over its links to the Russian Orthodox Church, seen by many as a tool of Moscow’s influence abroad.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Andreea Campeanu for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Sunday mass at the church in Rautel, Moldova. The community has been divided by differences over the Russian Orthodox Church.

item.title: Pentagon Warns ISIS Attacks Could Double This Year
item.description: Attacks claimed by ISIS in Iraq and Syria are on track to double last year’s total, the U.S. military said in a report, as the terrorist group’s affiliates become increasingly deadly elsewhere around the world.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Islamic State flag in a bombed-out militant headquarters in 2017 in Mosul, Iraq.

item.title: Plan to Rename Milan Airport After Silvio Berlusconi Sparks Protests
item.description: The decision to name Italy’s second-largest passenger hub after the divisive media mogul and politician, who died in 2023, has prompted outrage and protests.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Terminal 1 at Milan’s Malpensa Airport, which is now named International Airport Milan Malpensa — Silvio Berlusconi.

item.title: Wall St. Journal Reporter Says She Was Fired Over Hong Kong Union Role
item.description: The journalist accused her former employer of failing to stand up for press freedom, a claim that the newspaper rejected.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:description: Selina Cheng, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, was elected chair of the Hong Kong Journalists Association in June.

item.title: Traces of Cyanide Found in Bangkok Hotel Room Where Six Died
item.description: A case that shocked Thailand, the police indicated on Wednesday, was one of murder-suicide.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: A news conference Wednesday at a Bangkok police station about the six bodies found in a downtown hotel room.

item.title: Trump Says Taiwan Should Pay for U.S. Defense
item.description: Trump also accused Taiwan of sinking the U.S. semiconductor sector, signaling he wants a more transactional approach to shielding the island from China.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Former President Donald Trump backstage before entering the Convention Hall on the first day of the RNC Convention in Milwaukee on Monday.

item.title: A Guide to the King’s Speech: Crown Jewels, Black Rod and a Mace
item.description: When King Charles unveils the U.K. government’s agenda in Parliament, he is surrounded by rituals that nod to hundreds of years of history.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Allison McCann
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: In 2022, then-Prince Charles read the Queen’s Speech, filling in for Queen Elizabeth II, who missed the ceremony.

item.title: Hiker’s Death Prompts Move to Allow Wider Bear Cull in Romania
item.description: But some experts described the planned cull as excessive and said it would not keep people safe.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: A bear on a street in Covasna, a town in central Romania, last fall.

item.title: Paris Mayor Swims in Beautified Seine Ahead of Olympic Games
item.description: Anne Hidalgo swam in the cleaned-up waters of the capital’s river, fulfilling a promise that has become a symbol of the Olympic Games that start this month.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anne Hidalgo, the mayor of Paris, and Tony Estanguet, the head of the Paris Olympics Committee, prepared to swim in the Seine in central Paris on Wednesday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Biden’s third bout with Covid sidelined him as he was trying to re-energize his campaign in Nevada.

item.title: Marine Tondelier, the ‘Other Marine’ of French Politics, Hits Back
item.description: Marine Tondelier, leader of the Green Party, helped bring the left together to win France’s parliamentary elections. Now can she help keep it from falling apart?
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Marine Tondelier, the Green leader, applauding the results of the second round of France’s legislative election in Paris on July 7.

item.title: As Clouds Gather Over Europe, Leaders Seek Unity in Churchill’s Birthplace
item.description: More than 40 European leaders will meet at Blenheim Palace on Thursday. Fears over the continent’s security, and the threat of Russia, will loom large.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors to Blenheim Palace in 2019. European leaders are meeting there on Thursday.

item.title: In Argentina, Milei’s Devotion to Judaism Influences His Politics
item.description: Javier Milei has developed a public devotion to Judaism unusual for a leader of a predominantly Roman Catholic country.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Daniel Politi
item.media:description: President Javier Milei of Argentina, right, during an emotional visit to the Western Wall in Jerusalem in February with his rabbi, Shimon Axel Wahnish.

item.title: As Many South Koreans Shun Marriage, Two Women Try to Redefine Family
item.description: Hwang Sunwoo and Kim Hana, who are single and live together, say South Korea’s laws should reflect the alternative unions that many of its people have chosen.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hwang Sunwoo, left, and Kim Hana in Seoul. The two women, who have a best-selling book and a podcast, call themselves “a DIY family.”

item.title: Watch Rare Siamese Crocodiles Hatching
item.description: The largest population of the endangered Siamese crocodiles this century hatched in Cambodia, a big moment for the conservation of a wild species once on the brink of extinction.
item.dc:creator: Austyn Gaffney

item.title: Thursday Briefing: J.D. Vance Takes the Stage
item.description: Plus, Israel estimates the toll on Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Before this year, Senator J.D. Vance never attended a national political convention.

item.title: Britain Approves Lab-Grown Meat for Pet Food
item.description: British dogs and cats are set to become the first animals in Europe to chow down on meat cultivated from chicken cells.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: E.U. Court Rebukes European Commission Over Covid Vaccine Contracts
item.description: The court ruled that the European Commission wrongly withheld information, casting a shadow on its leader, Ursula von der Leyen, before a crucial vote on her future.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman received a Covid-19 vaccine near Paris in 2021. The European Union’s initial vaccine campaign was marred by a slow start.

item.title: In a Porridge Box, an Ancient Treasure Mysteriously Arrives in Dublin
item.description: The National Museum of Ireland received two copper Bronze Age ax heads in the mail. Now it needs to figure out who found them.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins

item.title: Moving in Childhood Contributes to Depression, Study Finds
item.description: A study of more than a million Danes found that frequent moves in childhood had a bigger effect than poverty on adult mental health risk.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Researchers found that people who moved more than once within the ages of 10 and 15 were 61 percent more likely to suffer from depression in adulthood compared to counterparts who had not moved.

item.title: Judge Orders Boss Who Coughed at Employee During Pandemic to Pay Damages
item.description: The ruling by a tribunal judge in Britain highlighted the challenges and missteps businesses encountered during the early days of the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Barriers in central London in 2020, set up to allow more room for pedestrians because of Covid-19 social distancing measures.

item.title: Israel’s Military Says It Eliminated Half the Leadership of Hamas Military Wing
item.description: The military said that it had killed or captured around 14,000 combatants in Gaza since the war’s start but left considerable ambiguity about the figure.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: The collapsed minaret of a mosque in Nuseirat, in the central Gaza Strip, on Wednesday.

item.title: World’s Rarest Whale Washes Up on New Zealand Beach
item.description: Only six specimens of the spade-toothed whale have ever been identified. This carcass could be the first that scientists are able to dissect.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: New Zealand Department of Conservation, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Scientists believe the carcass that washed up in Otogo, New Zealand, this month could give them their first opportunity to dissect a spade-toothed whale.

item.title: Biden vs. His Party
item.description: The Democratic Party’s Biden dilemma is unresolved, even as the momentum against him slows.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: President Biden last week.

item.title: Flash Flooding in Toronto Leads to Rescues and Power Outages
item.description: More than 167,000 customers lost power on Tuesday after severe thunderstorms.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Arlyn Mcadorey/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Cars are partially submerged in flood waters in the Don Valley following heavy rain in Toronto on Tuesday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: President Biden’s growing isolation.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The Democratic Party is still deeply divided about President Biden’s electoral prospects.

item.title: Vineyard Wind Turbine Breaks a Blade, Sending Pieces Ashore on Nantucket
item.description: It’s unclear why a blade from one of the Vineyard Wind turbines broke into pieces, which are washing up on Nantucket beaches.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Bob O'Connor for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers moved turbine blades for the Vineyard Wind offshore facility at the New Bedford Marine Commerce Terminal in Massachusetts last year.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: A Turbulent Moment in U.S. Politics
item.description: Plus, Israeli strikes killed more than 20 people in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden has said repeatedly that he is not leaving the race.

item.title: Former Syrian Official in Charge of Notorious Prison Is Arrested in Los Angeles
item.description: Samir Ousman al-Sheikh, who was seeking U.S. citizenship, is accused of falsely describing whether he persecuted anyone for their political beliefs or had been involved in any killings.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner and Adam Goldman
item.media:description: Adra prison on the outskirts of Damascus, Syria, in 2010. Former prisoners describe being starved, beaten, tortured and raped at the complex.

item.title: Bangladesh Deploys Border Force to Try to Quell Student Protests
item.description: Across the country, students have taken to the streets over job quotas that they say limit their opportunities.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Anupreeta Das
item.media:description: The student wing of the ruling party, Bangladesh Awami League, fighting with students protesting job quotas in the Dhaka College area in Bangladesh on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Detected Potential Iranian Plot to Kill Trump Separate From Saturday’s Shooting
item.description: American intelligence agencies were tracking an Iranian threat even before the attack on former President Donald J. Trump. But officials said the two were unrelated.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker, Adam Goldman and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Mr. Trump ordered a strike in 2020 that killed Maj. Gen. Qassim Suleimani, the Iranian security and intelligence commander responsible for the deaths of hundreds of American troops in Iraq over the years.

item.title: Fact-Checking the Republican National Convention on Energy Claims
item.description: Several speakers focused on the sharp rise in gas and electricity prices under President Biden. We scrutinized their statements.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer and Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Senator Marsha Blackburn of Tennessee speaking at the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee on Monday.

item.title: Rare Attack in Oman on Shiite Worshipers Leaves 6 People Dead
item.description: The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the shooting in the normally quiet Gulf nation.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: A screen grab from a video posted on social media purporting to show people fleeing the scene of a shooting near a mosque in Oman’s capital, Muscat.

item.title: Six People Found Dead in Bangkok Hotel Under Mysterious Circumstances
item.description: The police originally said the deaths were apparently caused by poison, but later walked that statement back.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: The police were blocking members of the media from entering the Grand Hyatt Erawan in central Bangkok, where three men and three women were found dead on Tuesday.

item.title: Pushing Quick End to Ukraine War, Orban Plays Trump’s Messenger to E.U.
item.description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary has been on a self-appointed diplomatic mission that aligns with Donald J. Trump’s preferences in the Russia-Ukraine conflict.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Zoltan Fischer/Agence France-Presse, via X Account of Hungary's Prime Minister
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump and Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary on Thursday at Mr. Trump’s Mar-a-Lago estate in a photograph released by Mr. Orban’s office.

item.title: The Poet Who Commands a Rebel Army
item.description: “Revolution is the job of poets and artists,” says Ko Maung Saungkha, leader of a rebel militia fighting the Myanmar dictatorship. He is not the only poet commander in a country with a strong tradition of political verse.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech and Daniel Berehulak
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Ko Maung Saungkha, center, a poet who is a rebel commander in Myanmar, on the first day of training for new recruits in Karen State, in May.

item.title: I.M.F. Sees Signs of Cooling in U.S. Economy
item.description: The International Monetary Fund warned that inflation remained stubbornly high and that protectionism posed a risk to the global economic outlook.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: A line for a South Florida job fair. “The United States shows increasing signs of cooling, especially in the labor market, after a strong 2023,” wrote Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas, the I.M.F.’s chief economist.

item.title: Vaughan Gething, First Minister of Wales, Resigns
item.description: Vaughan Gething became the first minister of Wales in March. But a growing controversy over campaign financing precipitated his decision to resign.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Ben Birchall/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Vaughan Gething in Cardiff in March, when he became the first Black person to lead a national government in Europe.

item.title: J.D. Vance’s Chance
item.description: Why Donald Trump tapped Vance to be his successor.
item.dc:creator: Michael C. Bender
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator J.D. Vance and his wife, Usha, at the convention last night.

item.title: Gareth Southgate Resigns as England Coach
item.description: Southgate’s eight years in charge made him the most successful England manager in decades. In stepping down two days after losing the Euro 2024 final, he got the last word.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Gareth Southgate coached England to the semifinals of the 2018 World Cup and the finals of two straight European Championships.

item.title: Surge in Violence by West Bank Settlers Draws Ire of Israel’s Allies
item.description: The European Union sanctioned settler extremists for ‘systematic human rights abuses against Palestinians,’ and rights groups say the Israeli military is complicit.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Inspecting damage at a construction material depot after a reported overnight attack by Israeli settlers, near the village of Bazariya in the West Bank on Friday.

item.title: Heavy Downpours and Flooding Kill Dozens Across South Asia
item.description: Climate change has created more intense monsoon seasons in the region, displacing millions and gutting buildings, bridges and villages.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Flooding in Assam, India, earlier this month.

item.title: North Korean Diplomat Defects to the South, Talks of Execution
item.description: Ri Il-kyu, who fled to South Korea late last year, alleged that two North Korean officials who had been assigned to negotiate with the Trump administration had been punished.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A file image of Ri Il-kyu, a senior North Korean diplomat who defected to the South last November, was aired on a news program in the South on Tuesday.

item.title: What Trump 2.0 Could Mean for the Environment
item.description: If Donald Trump returns to the White House, he would likely face fewer legal and bureaucratic obstacles to dramatically remake the E.P.A.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer and Lisa Friedman
item.category: Chevron v Natural Resources Defense Council (Supreme Court Decision)
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former president Trump has promised to repeal federal regulations designed to cut greenhouse gases.

item.title: NASA Sends a Missy Elliott Song to Space
item.description: NASA sent the song “The Rain (Supa Dupa Fly)” from a radio dish in California last week. It took 14 minutes to travel the 158 million miles.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: Missy Elliott performing at the Grammy Awards in Los Angeles last year.

item.title: Taiwan’s Blunt-Talking Leader Faces China’s Backlash
item.description: China is putting more military and political pressure on Taiwan and its new president, whose rhetoric has been sharper than his predecessor’s.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: President Lai Ching-te of Taiwan has used direct language to reject China’s claim to the island. “According to international law, we are already a sovereign and independent country,” he told Time magazine.

item.title: Masoud Pezeshkian Promises Change in Iran. Can He Deliver?
item.description: Masoud Pezeshkian, a widowed doctor, portrays himself as a reformer who can bring social and economic shifts. But others have tried and failed before him, and numerous obstacles are in his path.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Masoud Pezeshkian at a rally in Tehran on the last day of campaigning before the election. He ended up winning in an upset.

item.title: Dysfunction Sidelines Ukraine’s Parliament as Governing Force
item.description: With the president’s party split, the government relies on formerly pro-Russian lawmakers to help it pass legislation and, the opposition says, minimize scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: Servant of the People (Ukrainian Political Party)
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Independence Square in Kyiv. Ukraine’s Constitution assigns more power to the Parliament than the presidency. But the balance in wartime has been different.

item.title: Masha Gessen Sentenced in Absentia by Russian Court to 8 Years in Prison
item.description: Masha Gessen was found guilty of spreading “false information” and sentenced to eight years in prison over remarks made in 2022 about the Russian military.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Masha Gessen, shown in Germany last December, was found guilty of spreading “false information” about the Russian military by a court in Moscow.

item.title: J.D. Vance’s Opposition to U.S. Support for Ukraine: In His Own Words
item.description: “I don’t really care what happens to Ukraine one way or the other,” Senator Vance has said.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: J.D. Vance has been one of Congress’s most vocal opponents of U.S. aid for Ukraine.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Donald Trump’s Running Mate
item.description: Plus, a judge dismisses a criminal case against Trump.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: J.D. Vance, once a critic of Donald Trump, is now his running mate.

item.title: Israel in Talks Over Withdrawing From Egypt-Gaza Border, Officials Say
item.description: The discussions between Israeli and Egyptian officials comes amid diplomatic activity on several continents over a cease-fire deal and postwar plans for the territory.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Adam Rasgon, Vivian Wang and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: A view of Rafah in the Gaza Strip, seen from the Egyptian side of the border, this month.

item.title: South Korea Bans Everything Bagel Seasoning
item.description: The seasoning is sold by Trader Joe’s, a brand whose popularity has skyrocketed in the region in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson

item.title: J.D. Vance Is an Oil Booster and Doubter of Human-Caused Climate Change
item.description: He once said society had a climate problem but changed his position sharply while seeking Donald Trump’s endorsement in his Senate race.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Vance has accused the Biden administration of “wanton harassment of fossil fuel companies.”
